Sentence: Cheveley, an enemy of Lady Chiltern's from their school days, attempts to blackmail Sir Robert into supporting a fraudulent scheme to build a canal in Argentina

Cheveley pointedly informs Lady Chiltern of Sir Robert's change of heart regarding the canal scheme, the morally inflexible Lady, unaware of both her (Lady) husband's past and the blackmail plot, insists that Sir Robert renege on his (Robert) promise

For Lady Chiltern, their marriage is predicated on her (Chiltern) having an ', "``ideal husband'' (LadyChiltern)', '--that is, a model spouse in both private and public life that she (Chiltern) can worship: thus Sir Robert must remain unimpeachable in all his (Robert) decisions
He (Robert) also takes Lady Chiltern aside and obliquely urges her (Chiltern) to be less morally inflexible and more forgiving
Unable to accept a Sir Robert now unmasked, Lady Chiltern then denounces her (Chiltern) husband and refuses to forgive him (Robert)
Lady Chiltern then appears, and Lord Goring informs her (Chiltern) that Sir Robert's letter has been destroyed but that Mrs
At that moment, Sir Robert enters while reading Lady Chiltern's letter, but he (Robert) has mistaken it for a letter of forgiveness written for him (Robert)
The ever-upright Lady Chiltern then attempts to drive Sir Robert to renounce his (Robert) career in politics, but Lord Goring dissuades her (Chiltern) from doing so
